Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Anna Michelle Wright of Wayne State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Are people from different cultures more willing to replace their memories with technology?" during the summer of 2012 at Seoul National University in Seoul, South Korea. The host scientist is Dr. Incheol Choi.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is multifaceted. This research project is the first laboratory examination of the effect of video camera presence on later recall of events. Specifically, this research project examines whether individuals who are confident they can refer back to a video recording of an event distribute that information into the environment (i.e., recall less information than individuals who believe the video recording to be unreliable or unavailable). Completion of this research project in South Korea allows the researchers to examine a memory "off-loading" effect in a cross-cultural setting. As such, the study provides information about the generality of mechanisms of human memory and human cognition.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background and Purpose: The tendency to rely upon external sources to supplement memory has been referred to as distributed cognition. This study examined whether individuals who are confident that they can refer back to a video recording of an event distribute that information into the environment (i.e., recall less information than individuals who believe the video recording to be unreliable or unavailable). This distributed cognition approach was also combined with cross-cultural psychology by comparing episodic recall for those from a more collectivist culture (i.e., South Koreans) with those from a more individualist culture (i.e., students from the United States--data collection for the U.S. sample is currently underway). 

 

Overview of Design: This study examined the relationship between saliency of video camera presence during encoding and recall of laboratory tasks. A total of 51 participants from a collectivist culture were recruited to participate and were randomly assigned into one of two conditions, 1.) no video camera present in the room, and 2.) video camera present/recording and ostensibly available for later use during the recall phase. Participants completed seven tasks and were then asked to recall specific details about the events including recall for colors, numbers, order, spatial arrangements, words, smells, and other details.  Recall of the completed laboratory tasks were examined through both free recall, forced recall, and memory phenomenology.

 

Preliminary Results: Care should be taken when examining these results, as data collection and analysis are still underway. The preliminary results, however, indicate distributed cognition may differ by memory type (i.e., differences in semantic vs. episodic memory), within memory type (i.e., differences in memory for colors vs. memory for numbers and scores), and even by recall measure (i.e., differences in forced recall vs. memory phenomenology).  

 

Project Outcomes: This research trained the PI in a new experimental methodology and also provided experience with an international research project. The PI was also able to gain insight into the scientific culture and infrastructure of South Korea as well as share with fellow lab mates about the scientific culture in the U.S. Indeed, this collaborative project helped foster professional relationships between the PI and the Research Host, Seoul National University graduate students, and other experimental psychologists in South Korea. This research also provided two undergraduate research assistants at Seoul National University with first-hand experience of cognitive and social experimental research methodology.

Additional outcomes relevant to cognitive and experimental psychology are expected once data collection and analysis are complete. 

 

Publications/Presentations: The preliminary findings from this project were presented at the Korean Psychological Association Annual Conference in Gangchon, South Korea in August 2012. Once the project is complete the resulting manuscript will be submitted for peer review.
